Getting started#

OpenVariant is a comprehensive package to parse and operate different input file formats in a customized way. Its aim is being able to manage a ton of data represented in multiple ways and be able to build a unified output with a proper annotation file structure. This package was thought not only to work with biological data, also, it can be used to any kind of data that can be represented as a table.

OpenVariant offers a toolkit to transform and operate the parsed input data. Through this User guide you will be able to do a walk-through of all its different functionalities. Even so, one of the main things of OpenVariant is the annotation structure which the package is based. This kind of annotation structure will describe how input files will be parsed and how the output will be represented. It is important to know how it works and how it is composed, in order to manage data in the best way possible and later on performance a decent analysis. In the following section you will learn how the annotation files have to be built and what are the key factors to get the most out.

  • Annotation structure
    • Pattern (required)
    • Format (optional)
    • Columns (optional)
    • Annotation (required)
      • Static
      • Internal
      • Filename
      • Dirname
      • Mapping
      • Plugin
    • Exclude (optional)

For deeper detail of how it works and which are the actions that you can perform, take a look into Tasks and Command-line interface (CLI) sections. In addition, for more advance features, check: Plugin system. If you want to try out or have some doubts on how to set it up, check our Installation section and take a look into the multiple Examples that we built. In case that you want to be engage and contribute to the project, follow our Contribution guide.
